intro: Guillauminia bellatula, commonly known as the desert bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and is adapted to withstand high temperatures and low water availability. Its leaves are narrow and covered in a fine layer of white hairs, which help reduce water loss. The flowers, which range in color from white to pale blue, bloom in late spring and early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
